results.title: Cumberland story
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit, Alexander Shaw and Humphrey Jennings
results.brief_description: A dramatised documentary, made for the Ministry of Fuel and Power, aiming to reassure miners about the proposed nationalisation of the coal fields. Revolves around the dramatic tale of a disaster which involved the loss of many lives almost 100 years earlier. The seam located under the sea floor is opened up again for working, and with modern equipment and safety devices, there is little likelihood of a repetition of the old tragedy. Many of the roles are performed by the actual workers, Nimmo is played by a mining engineer and Stephenson is one of the mine leaders. Cinematography, Chick Fowle. Music, Arthur Benjamin performed by the Philharmonic Orchestra. Made in collaboration with the United Steel Companies and the National Union of Mine-Workers.

results.title: Cultures of mothering
results.creator_credit: Monash University and Robert de Young
results.brief_description: Mothering is an issue that demands attention, but is often only brought in the public arena on the rather commercialised Mother’s Day. Mothering is a significant part of life that is not often considered as a separate issue for women. This program addresses mothering in Australian society and raises the level of debate about issues relating to mothering. Mothering is looked at over generations as well as its changing identity in contemporary society today. Mothering across cultures, the status of mothering, sexuality and mothering, as well as stereotypes are explored within this program, giving voice to a number of women who share their experiences of mothering. Produced by the Monash University Centre for Women’s Studies.

results.title: Cultured pearls
results.brief_description: The complete process of pearl culture. Women divers take oysters from the seabed, which are injected with tissue and kernels, and placed in wire baskets to mature in warm sea water in bays and inlets. A careful watch is kept on the temperature and conditions of the sea, and the oysters are moved in the water as necessary. The shells are cleaned once a year, until harvesting, when the pearls are removed, graded, inspected and made up for dealers.

results.title: Culture, time & place
results.creator_credit: DLGHS, GPN, George A. Colburn and Darrel Schwandt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Language, schooling and the interactions of everyday life are vehicles of acculturation that communicate values, beliefs, attitudes and expectations to children. Observing a traditional Japanese religious festival, we explore the myth and ritual which help children see their relationship to time, place and values.

results.title: Culture Club: a kiss across the ocean
results.creator_credit: Virgin Vision, Keefco Productions, Hugh Symonds and Keef
results.brief_description: Recorded live at Hammersmith Odeon, December 1983. The charismatic Boy George and his band Culture Club perform some of their most loved songs in this very enjoyable and entertaining concert. The band, made up of Boy George, Jon Moss, Roy Hay, and Mikey Craig are supported by the fabulous Helen Terry as back-up vocal.

results.title: Culture change
results.creator_credit: Coast Community College District, Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Ira R. Abrams and Harry Ratner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 23 of Series “Faces of culture”.
The most important aspect of any culture is the ability to adapt and change. Change can be revolution, change may walk quietly and speak softly, change may come from inside a culture through a leader of vision. The sources of change may be technological, environmental or ideological. This program looks at good and bad aspects of change, in particular at the cargo cults of New Guinea, colonial India and the jungles of Brazil. Narrated by David Carradine.

results.title: Culture as nature
results.creator_credit: BBC, Time-Life Films, RM Productions, Lorna Pegram and David Richardson
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Shock of the New Series”.
Fifty years ago our culture became that of the mass media, crammed with stimuli, an overload of advertising and technology. The late 19th century saw the arrival of industrial imagery; then it was the sign and print which dominated. In this fight between painting and media, art could not win. Pop sensibility’s good side was letting art react to mass culture; its bad side was the manipulation of promotional garbage. Yet even in today’s culture, man is judgemental - choice and taste may yet preserve the responsibility of painting. Written and narrated by Robert Hughes.

results.title: Culture and recreation
results.creator_credit: Motion Picture Associates, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and John Leake
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia in the 80’s”.
A non-narrated montage of images showing aspects of culture and recreation in Australia, interspersed with some historic footage. Shows sport, dance, historic buildings, the Sydney Opera House, opera performances and festivals. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
